Award.AwardTitle: The energy -water resources interface: A model for complex systems analysis in rural Wyoming middle schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Energy and water are major constraints to global prosperity and directly pertinent to global climate change. Their interface is of particular relevance to Wyoming as the leading US state in the exportation of energy but having major water limitations. As a model for illustrating principles of complexity and uncertainty in science, the energy-water interface presents a relevant framework to enhance STEM learning outcomes. In addition, like many rural, frontier states, Wyoming faces distinct challenges with respect to STEM awareness, education, and career opportunities. And a significant proportion of the state population can be categorized as at-risk relative to socio-economic status and educational achievement. These challenges will be addressed through a partnership between schools, the University, and the private sector using a diverse portfolio of activities designed to increase learning outcomes of doctoral fellows, 7-10 grade students and teachers, to inform career choice through motivating STEM experiences, and to institutionalize GK12 goals in the graduate education infrastructure of UW. Specific deliverables from this project include: inquiry based curricular units, summer research experiences, diverse workshops, multiple training events, sustained cyberinfrastructure interactions, and global research opportunities. This program will promote the competitive success of the future STEM workforce by providing training in leadership, communication and project management skills for graduate fellows, by enhancing the educational pipeline through motivational awareness units, through sustained professional development of teachers, and by development of new interdisciplinary graduate programs focused on GK12 objectives.

University of Wyoming Science Posse: Connecting Scientists and Students to Inspire the Next Generation of Scientists, Engineers and Mathematicians

 

In labs at the University of Wyoming in Laramie and in classrooms across the state, PhD students in red shirts challenged students to investigate the properties of polymers, characterize herbivore and carnivore skulls, or design a successful solar vehicle. These red shirted PhD students were members of the University of Wyoming Science Posse, a unique GK-12 outreach program to promote science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) in the state of Wyoming.

From 2006 to 2015, supported by two NSF GK-12 grants, the Science Posse connected its Fellows with teachers and students across the state of Wyoming. The Posse’s goals were to inspire students to become the next generation of STEM professionals, to inform teachers about current research trends and best practices in science teaching, and to improve the graduate students' abilities to communicate technical subjects to non-technical audiences.

In those nine years, the Science Posse traveled to all twenty-three Wyoming counties and worked with over 131 schools/programs in thirty-four of Wyoming’s forty-eight school districts. The Posse worked with 162 teachers and 26,821 students, an average of 3,400 students per school year. In addition, the Posse provided summer enrichment activities for 297 students and summer professional development to 166 teachers. Forty-nine Fellows were supported by the grant. Thirty-eight completed their degrees; eighteen are now in higher education, one is a high school mathematics teacher in a STEM magnet school, nine are working in industry, and three are working for state and federal governments. Nine more are on track to graduate by spring 2016.

During the school year, the Science Posse Fellows worked with any Wyoming educator who requested them through the Science Posse website. Teachers brought their students to campus or the Fellows visited students in their school, institution, or after school program, either in person, or virtually using the University’s Blackboard Collaborate platform. These visits connected students with scientists, engineers, and mathematicians who provided first hand knowledge of their research with engaging hands-on activities. Fellows’ career/research talks helped students learn how the Fellows became scientists and what they do as scientists. Mini-lessons were short, engaging, and dynamic activities that made students say, "WOW, science is cool!” Fellows also developed specialized lessons tied directly with a teacher’s curriculum that showed students their classroom learning is relevant and connected to what happens in the real world. To improve student science fair entries, Fellows provided science fair overviews for students in classrooms (and parents at family science nights), as well as individual or small group consultations that helped students understand the process, design their experiments, and analyze their data.

Summers meant collaborating with groups both inside and outside the University to provide student enrichment and teacher professional development. The weeklong Exploring Science Middle School in Grand Teton National Park was a partnership with the Teton Science Schools in Jackson, Wyoming. The High School Energy Summer Institute was a collaboration between the Science Posse, the School of Energy Resources and the EENanotechnology GK-12 Project. Teacher professional development involved partnerships between the Posse and the Wyoming NASA Space Grant Consortium, i-STEM (Idaho-Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math), WYSTEM (Wyoming K-14 STEM Engagement Project), and the University of Wyoming Art Museum.
